awd_titl_txt: Effects of International Migration on Land Use and Conservation in Mexico
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Nora M. Haenn (North Carolina State University), in collaboration with researchers at El Colegio de la Frontera Sur in Mexico, will undertake research on the interactions between rainforest conservation and migration from Mexico to the United States.  One-fourth of Mexico's parks and protected areas are located in the southern parts of that country, places where large-scale international migration has only recently become the norm.  Because southern Mexico is also home to tropical ecosystems, the research asks how migration affects rainforest conservation.  

The researchers will investigate the impact of international migration on rainforest protection by surveying 200 rural families living on the border of the Calakmul Biosphere Reserve.  Calakmul is Mexico's largest protected area for tropical ecosystems.  The survey will pose questions on agricultural and forestry activities, migration, and remittances.  The investigators previously carried out similar surveys in Calakmul, when international migration from this region was unusual.  By comparing past findings with current land use and migration trends, the research aims to identify the impact of migration on forest cover. 

The research is significant because it will address the connections between two significant trends in the contemporary world: on-going land cover change and dynamic international labor migration. These topics are not usually linked in either social science theory or policy development. But because local conservation efforts are increasingly focused on local household participation, even as adult male household heads are frequently working abroad, investigation of those linkages is critical. The research also builds ties between U.S. and Mexican institutions and supports student education.

Mexico is one of the world’s most biodiverse countries, and in the last thirty years has expanded considerably the number and size of its national parks, biosphere reserves, and other protected areas. Given its tropical climate, many of these protected areas are located in the country’s south, a region that joined the international migration stream at the turn of the new century. Given that one-fourth of Mexico’s parks and protected areas are located in states where large-scale international migration has only recently become the norm, this project posed questions aimed at exploring the relationship between international migration and environmental conservation. How does migration change the finances and land use of farm families living near protected areas? How have forums aimed at increasing public participation in conservation respond to the significant growth in international migration?

 The research took place in the municipio or county of Calakmul, home to Mexico’s largest protected rain forest, the Calakmul Biosphere Reserve. Data collection occurred in two parts. One part entailed collaborating with Mexican colleagues at El Colegio de la Frontera Sur to carry out a survey of 225 Calakmul households. In this way, one of the project’s broader impacts included enhancing infrastructure for research through international collaboration with an interdisciplinary, post-graduate school for environmental studies. Data collection incorporated ECOSUR graduate students as surveyors and database entry personnel. Surveyors also included Native Americans from Mexico and a Latino from the United States. The second part entailed attending and documenting local town hall-style meetings that dealt with questions of conservation. Another of the project’s broader impacts focused on making findings available to these local policy-makers through personal and radio presentations, as well as through printed handouts.

 The survey found that 47% of Calakmul households had at least one member travel to the United States at some point in time (many have since returned). Ongoing data analysis is exploring how remittances from these individuals might have been invested in farm enterprises, housing construction, or some other endeavor that impacts conservation. Preliminary analysis reveals some surprising findings regarding the role that poverty relief programs in Mexico may play in supporting international migration. Mexico has been praised in the international arena for its cash transfer program known as Opportunities. Opportunities supports women and children with financial stipends. While the survey found that families receiving Opportunities were neither more nor less likely to have a member migrate to the United States, at the same time, Calakmul residents widely share the idea that migrant families use these monies to make it through the first few months of a husband and father’s trip abroad, when he is just getting his bearing in the United States and is unable to send money.

 Despite migration’s prevalence, attendance at town hall meetings showed that local environmental policy-makers rarely consider the topic in their discussions. International migration in this part of the world has a significant economic impact. The research estimated some 2.5 million U.S. dollars enter the county each year. This amount compares with about one million dollars spent on environmental programming in the region. Migration is a relatively new economic strategy for Calakmul, with significant financial consequences. Local policy-makers, however, do not consider the matter.
